Legal_Issue: Whether the medical officers erred in concluding that Samuel Man's admission would cause excessive demands on social services
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; original decision invalidated
Evidence_Type: Evidence that Samuel could work in a sheltered workshop but not in the open labor market
Basis_of_Claim: Potential excessive demand on social services due to mental disability
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to assess whether social services were limited or inaccessible under s. 22(e) of the Regulations
Application_Error: Failure to consider limitations or accessibility of sheltered workshop services as required by s. 22(e)
Evidence_Ignored: Lack of consideration of availability and accessibility of sheltered workshop services
Application_Factor: Health impairment potentially causing excessive demand on social services
Decision_Review_Issue: Error in law by medical officers in applying s. 22(e)
Governing_Rule_or_Provision: s. 19(1)(a)(ii), Immigration Act; s. 22(e), Immigration Regulations
Outcome_of_Review: Original decision set aside, remitted for reconsideration
Cause_of_Refusal: Mental disability and potential reliance on social services
Legal_Provision_Cited: s. 19(1)(a)(ii), Immigration Act; s. 22(e), Immigration Regulations
Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to assess evidence regarding service availability
Procedural_Fairness: Failure to properly apply regulatory assessment requirements
Legal_Defense_or_Challenge: Challenge based on incorrect legal interpretation by medical officers
Jurisdictional_Focus: Immigration and refugee law, Canadian jurisdiction
Relevant_Law: Immigration Act, s. 19(1)(a)(ii); Immigration Regulations, s. 22(e)
Procedural_Issue: Failure to follow proper procedural assessment under regulations
Omission_Type: Failure to consider required regulatory factor (service limitations)
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility: Excessive demand on social services due to health condition
